name: 陳文輝
objective:
This course integrates foundational training in object-oriented programming with practical applications relevant to smart living technologies (Course No. 350096).  
Students will develop essential programming skills through exercises and projects, with a strong emphasis on OOP principles such as encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism. In addition to foundational OOP topics, the course explores real-world applications, including recent advancements in vision-language models and their integration into autonomous driving systems. 
Students will engage in critical reading and discussion of cutting-edge research papers to understand how OOP techniques support complex AI systems.
Some parts of the course will be co-taught by a doctoral teaching assistant providing additional support and insights into advanced topics.
schedule:
Week 1: Course Introduction, Logistics, and Student Background Survey
-Overview of course objectives and requirements
-Survey on programming experience and autonomous driving knowledge
Week 2: Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) Concepts
-Basics of OOP: abstraction, encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism
Week 3: Classes, Objects, and Encapsulation Fundamentals
Weeks 4–6: Object-Oriented Design Patterns
-Introduction and exercises
Weeks 7–8: Inheritance, Polymorphism, and Advanced OOP Concepts
-Paper reading & discussion session: Introduction to Vision-Language Models in AD
Week 9: Paper discussion continued 
Week 10: Midterm Exam.
Weeks 11–12: OOP programming & object-oriented data analysis applications
Weeks 13–14: Paper Reading & Discussions on vision-language models in AD
-Critical analysis of recent research papers
-Guided discussions
Weeks 15–16: OOP programming & industrial system development
-Case studies and project work
Weeks 17–18: Final project presentations
scorePolicy:
1. Weekly Programming Assignments (25%)	
2. Paper Reading & Discussion Reports (15%) 
3. Midterm Examination (20%)
4. Final Project (30%) 
5. Class Participation (10%)

Students enrolling in this course should expect to spend 6–8 hours per week outside of class on reading, coding, and project development.
materials:
1. Instructor-prepared lecture slides 
2. Selected readings from recent publications
